text: I think that we‚Äôll use chatgpt in the future, Maybe you can create a Python script with some useful functions to use it easily for our future works
not sure either. Maybe trying to read some paper to compare other's work. I donno
Yes it's probably better this way. It might be useful since our messages are short, so even stopwords are importat
Also I'm not sure about what I should be working on, so if you have a specif task in mind let me know so I'll do it

yeah, probably
but maybe transformers are complex enough to ignore those words themselves. I mean they have been trained on huge amount of data ...
We can postpone it for later and implement it if the model performance was not high enough
Maybe deleting the stopword from the message will help with the embdedding

yeah, that's true for all the embeddings. The model would be more accurate if we take into account a group of messages as a single messages does not include the whole topic/context and they are usually short messages

Concept drift detectors are used to detect if a change in the distribution of the data arises.

Since laser embedding maps the sentences with similar semantic in a close region, if the  topic changes also the distribution of the vectors related to the new topic should change with respect to the previous one

That's true...
At least for most cases üëç
For change topic detection also the concept drift detectors could be used in some way
I was thinking that Maybe we could avoid to translate the messages beforehand, usually when a conversatiom is in English, if there is a new message in italian it is not related to the same topic

The other methods I looked up for detecting the changes was Density based clustering (like DBSCAN) but for this one we have to indicate the minimum number of points for a neighborhood/cluster 

And i guess this one is better for detecting the change but the trade off it's the issue we talked about yesterday, in which the distance between the vectors of the messages to be considered a "change" varies based on the time span of the messages we're looking at

Overall with the clustering methods you have to indicate for the method to group the messages
Also this one is doing smt similar...

As you said, we have to assume that all messages can be labeled, however in real data the messages may not have the context(crucial words) to being labeled, so that would affect the performance drastically...
That's my guess
agreed

By using k-means we have to come up with all the labels we want to know and assume that all the messages would fit into the labels we considered (the downside is that the accuracy will be lowered given some messages probably will not fit into the labels) but I guess it's one of the easier ways to go with

On Detecting Changes in Statistical Data
Signals .....

oh, sorry, I forgot to respond to this one. xd
From user ids we can track down the actual users.
but if we use only the hashes of ids we wouldn't have any data relating messages and actual telegram users.

In general
If we want to do smt with the embeddings and detect changes in patterns using neural networks
we need RNN structure or Transformer to handle sequential inputs
If you found anything interesting send it here

text: The user id is already in the dataset if i‚Äôm not wrong

I‚Äôm trying to build an RNN model to detect changes in topics from a timeline of messages. I‚Äôm using a sentence transformer to embed each message and feeding these embeddings one by one to detect if the topic has changed or if it is related to the previous messages. In addition to the embeddings, I want to add user data. I do not want to profile users, but adding the information that these two messages has been sent by the same user. How can I add this data to my embedding?

ChatGPT:
You can incorporate user information into your embeddings by using a technique called feature concatenation. Here‚Äôs a general idea of how you can do it:

User ID Encoding: Assign a unique ID to each user and use one-hot encoding or an embedding layer to convert these IDs into fixed-length vectors. This will allow your model to learn and understand user-specific characteristics.
Concatenation: After you have both the message embeddings (from Sentence Transformer) and user embeddings (from User ID Encoding), you can concatenate these two vectors to form a new input vector. This new vector now contains information from both the message and the user.
Sorry i got caught up in the middle of something and I forgot to send it, I'll send it now

text:
Hello Prof. Pernici,

We wanted to update you on how the project is going and what we plan to do. 

We had a meeting with PoliNetwork associates this week, they gave us an unofficial approval, but they said they have to talk back with the association's board and will give us the feedback.

For now we have started testing methods that you sent us (Laser Embedding and sentence transformer).

Also, we have implemented the script in which we are going to use¬†to gather the data.

As for the next steps for the coming days we plan to work on the data gathering pipeline and the preprocessing stage, As well as reading more about the the embedding techniques and the best approach we can take for detecting the change of topic in a conversation.

Here is a link to our GitHub repo:
https://github.com/amirmosio/telegram-event-detection
